Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Neural Bases of Semantic Composition in the Verb Phrase

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The richness of natural language semantics stems from the ability to compose elements together and to derive novel meanings from these combinations. Understanding this ability has been a central goal in the neurobiology of language, as well as in theoretical linguistics. However, despite a rapidly growing body of research, the brain basis of composition has been vaguely understood at best. Most of the progress during the last decade has been limited to general descriptions of the sentence level, identifying a network of brain areas recruited for the composition of sentential meaning but not further specifying how the individual facets of sentence composition are encoded. Considering the assumption in formal semantics that composition can happen via at least two different rules, understanding very basic instances of composition in various linguistic environments is an essential first step for characterizing the neural basis of sentence interpretation. To this end, this dissertation takes a bottom-up approach, investigating neural substrates of small units of composition, with its focus on English verb phrases. Disentangling the two major modes of composition around a verb, namely modification (e.g., paint + slowly) and saturation of arguments (e,g., paint + a picture), this work aims to provide an answer to the question of how the meaning of a complex event description, e.g., "John reluctantly painted a picture," is composed from the various event elements, i.e., John (agent), reluctantly (manner), painted (action), and a picture (object). This work aims to lay a critical foundation for a computationally detailed characterization of full sentence composition.

This dissertation consists of three studies that take advantage of the high spatiotemporal resolution of magnetoencephalography to characterize the dynamics of composition. The first experiment investigates the neural signatures of modification in the verbal domain, asking how the combination of a verb and its modifier engages the brain, and how this overall pattern compares to that of noun-modifier combination, for which stable results have been described in prior work. The second experiment investigates the neural representation of conceptual specificity in the event domain. Previous literature has shown that a particular brain region, the left anterior temporal lobe (LATL), is sensitive to conceptual specificity in the object domain (e.g., boat vs. canoe). Asking whether event specificity also involves the same area in the same way, the second experiment manipulates the conceptual specificity of events (e.g., "hoard fuel" vs "store fuel"). The last experiment explores situations of (possible) semantic composition in which the combining words do not form a syntactic constituent. In all, these studies combine insights from theoretical linguistics and from the psychological literature on concepts and categories to elucidate the neural reflexes of event composition as manifested in verb phrase interpretation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the neural underpinnings of semantic combinatory operations in the domain of the event concepts. The ability to combine elements together and derive novel meanings from the combination is a quintessential feature of human language faculty. While understanding this ability has been a central goal in the neurobiology of language, the brain basis of composition has been only vaguely understood; most of the progress during the last decade has been limited to descriptions of the sentence level, broadly identifying the ‘combinatory network’ in the brain, or, on a sub-sentential level, focused on the composition of a particular type, such as a noun phrase. Formal semantics theory, however, has laid out an elaborate and comprehensive theory of composition, which assumes a basic inventory of combinatory operations applying to any grammatical categories, such as Function Application and Predicate Modification. Motivated by the formal semantics theory, this project aimed to understand how basic combinations in the verb phases are represented in the brain, using magnetoencephalography (MEG).

     This project consisted of three MEG experiments. The first experiment investigated the neural signatures of modification in the verbal domain, asking how the combination of a verb and its modifier engages the brain. We found that the adverb-verb composition engages the left anterior temporal lobe (LATL) at around 250ms, similarly in the adjective-noun composition. Furthermore, the semantics of adverbs turned out to manipulate the LATL activity in a parallel way as the semantics of adjectives does. This supports a cross-categorical profile of combinatory computation in the LATL.

     The second study continued to explore the composition of adverbs but in an extended syntactic environment, namely a full sentence. Unlike the first study that investigated the adverb-verb composition, the second study asked how adverbs integrate with a noun argument, when the adverbs’ meaning describe a property of an noun argument (e.g., “John reluctantly painted a picture,” where the property of being reluctant applies to the agent of painting). The combination of the adverb and the noun again activated the LATL, suggesting that the adverbs directly integrate with the relevant event-participant noun, despite the fact that their combination (i.e., adverb + noun) does not form a syntactic constituent on their own. Such a pattern suggests that the combinatory operation in the LATL may not require syntactic constituency of the operands.

     The last study investigated the neural signatures of verb – argument composition. Previous research on combinatory computation has shown that conceptual specificity of individual words mediates the composition-related activity found in the LATL. We tested whether a qualitatively similar pattern extends to verb-argument combinations, varying conceptual specificity in simple sentences consisting of subject, verb, and object. Results showed an overall similar modulation by conceptual specificity in the verb domain, suggesting a central, category-insensitive, role for the LATL as a conceptual combiner. Apart from the LATL, specificity effects were also found in the left mid-superior temporal cortex. But the left angular gyrus, an area which is often hypothesized as one of the combinatory nodes, did not show any effect of conceptual specificity or verb-argument composition effect. Overall, the results suggest a general mechanism in the LATL that composes not only noun concepts, but also propositions describing events.

     By combining insights from theoretical linguistics and from the neuro- or psychological literature on concepts and categories, this study has elucidated the neural reflexes of event composition as manifested in verb phrase interpretation. It also provided a detailed description of how basic combinatory operations assumed in the linguistic literature unfolds over time and across regions in the brain, using MEG, which will serve a useful reference for the field in the future. The results of this project can also be potentially beneficial to the clinical population whose ability to process verb phrases is compromised.
